title: Penelope's Experiences in Scotland; Being Extracts from the Commonplace Book of Penelope Hamilton
author: Wiggin, Kate Douglas Smith
snippet: In their places stalked the ghosts ofkings and queens and knights and nobles; Columba, Abbot of Iona; QueenMargaret and Malcolm--she the sweetest saint in all the throng; KingDavid riding towards Drumsheugh forest on Holy Rood day, with his hornsand hounds and huntsmen following close behind; Anne of Denmark andJingling Geordie; Mary Stuart in all her girlish beauty, with the fourMaries in her train; and lurking behind, Bothwell, 'that ower sunestepfaither,' and the murdered Rizzio and Darnley; John Knox, in hisblack Geneva cloak; Bonnie Prince Charlie and Flora Macdonald; lovelyAnnabella Drummond; Robert the Bruce; George Heriot with a bannerbearing on it the words 'I distribute chearfully'; James I. carryingThe King's Quair; Oliver Cromwell; and a long line of heroes, martyrs,humble saints, and princely knaves.

title: Penelope's progress :
author: Wiggin, Kate Douglas Smith
snippet: places stalked the ghosts of kings and queens and knights and nobles : Columba, Abbot of lona ; Queen Margaret and Malcolm she the sweetest saint in all the throng; King David riding towards  Drumsheugh forest on Holy Rood-day, with his horns and hounds and huntsmen following close behind ; Anne of Denmark and Jingling Geordie ; Mary Stuart in all her girlish beauty, with the four Maries in her train ; and lurking behind,  Bothwell, " that ower sune stepfaither," and the murdered Rizzio and Darnley; John Knox, in his black Geneva cloak ; Bonnie Prince Charlie and Flora Macdonald ; lovely Annabella Drummond ; Robert the Bruce ; George Heriot with a banner bearing on it the words " I distribute  chearfully ; " James I. carrying The King's Quair; Oliver Cromwell ; and a long line of heroes,  martyrs, humble saints, and princely knaves.

title: The works of Robert Louis Stevenson;
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
snippet: Of James I., " ses chansons et ses ballades forment un recueil appele ' King's Quair ' " (p. 65); Sidney's "Arcadia" is " ce poeme " (p. 89); Walton's "Angler" is in the same case (pp. 237-8), and M. Filon even qualifies the versification : " des vers aussi reguliers, aussi tranquilles," etc.

title: Dreamthorp:
author: Smith, Alexander
snippet: In the concluding stanza of the " Quair," James records his obligation to those —

title: Song and scenery;
author: Moffat, James C.
snippet: author of ** The King's Quair," the reformer of the Scottish Monarchy, the first to estabhsh a government  of law over all Scotland, the first, and one of the very few monarchs of his country to go among the people familiarly, to learn of their wants, is known to only few as anything more than the first in a long line of Jameses, and by fewer as an unfortunate prince, who wrote a poem in a very obscure age, whose life began with a long imprisonment,  and ended by assassination.

title: Spare hours.
author: Brown, John
snippet: And the Quair bum singing doun to the vale o' Tweed.
